ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: i learned about african-american history through a black feminist lens and strengthened my writing skills.

I developed a lot of critical reading and thinking skills. We read many different types of books forcing us to learn how to read each different book, thus improving our reading skills. Furthermore the discussion time made it necessary to improve analytical skills as well.

Strong ability to read the texts in this course and discuss them in the context of the rest of the course. Ability to integrate Professor Lafargue's historical teachings into our understandings of the texts.

This was a great class to get a deeper insight into contemporary Black history in the United States and garner a good understanding of Black politics. I learned how to find patterns and trends throughout history and how specific events and issues have evolved over time. We read books by leading scholars and learned about notable female activists such as Angela Davis and Ella Baker. We learned about the pioneers of various Black social movements throughout history and how these movements were formed. I was able to learn about important issues such as Black uprisings, policing, mass incarceration, the AIDS epidemics disproportionate impact on the Black community, Black feminism, and disenfranchisement in the US.

-close analysis of readings 
-critical thinking about readings and topics (note cards were super valuable)
seeing trends in Black social movements across time, knowledge regarding what exactly a methodology is and how history is studied
Taught a pretty familiar period of history through some unique lenses--really enjoyed the emphasis on methodology, feminist frameworks, and organizing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: great books/reading list, passionate/knowledgeable professor

weaknesses: long seminar meant sometimes lack of student engagement

I feel like the best thing for this course would be to spread out the final paper over multiple assignments. By creating an assignment for thesis or for sources, I would have been much better prepared for the final paper
Very strong discussions and great text selection.
Really great texts, Professor is really good at leading conversations and providing context

One strength of this course is the weekly readings. Each book we read was engaging, insightful, and thought-provoking. I thoroughly enjoyed the material we read about and discussed in class, and I genuinely looked forward to doing the reading each week. I like that this class is in a seminar format, as our weekly discussions helped me to understand the content better and look at the material from various angles. All of the assignments in this class were straightforward and reasonable to complete as well.

-really interesting readings
-I really liked the note card questions we did at the beginning of class, it was a good way to stimulate ideas and spark a conversation whilst still giving students space to explore and take the conversation in whatever direction they choose 
-I liked the short responses, and they did help me think about my research paper 

-Sometimes I wish that once a conversation began to dwindle/ideas were reiterated, a slightly more direct prompt was given to give the conversation a little more oomph

strength: the books were phenomenal! And the material discussed is unique as I have not seen any other course like it. The information taught in this course is what every single Yale student should be familiar with. 
weakness: the speed at which we had to read the books made it so that we rushed through material or that I couldn't finish the books at times even though I really enjoyed the material. The speed combined with having the course once a week made it so that we barely got through the surface level in the conversations
Improved: more broken up reading assignments and more varied activities during class to mix up the predictable routine of notecard-surface level discussion-end of class (for example, the activity where we split up into groups and looked at Angela Davis' wanted poster was a good way to mix up the routine and keep us engaged); also, I think the Boundaries of Blackness book in particular should be given a lot more time given its more theoretical and academic language that was confusing to some

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: i would recommend this course to anyone interested in black history in the US. although it's a bit foundational at some parts for those who already have experience within the field, i think there is plenty to learn in going back and re-evaluating through the lens the course presents it through.
Yes, I felt like the material was very interesting and Professor Lafargue is excellent at initiating discussion and keeping it flowing and interesting.
YES!!! I loved this course so much. Professor Lafargue is a phenomenal teacher and chooses excellent texts to read. Everyone should try to take this course, regardless of their major/other interests.
Yes, I think the reading list alone is good enough reason, I learned a lot about AFAM history and about the study of history more broadly. Great seminar!

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to other students. This is one of my favorites classes I have taken at Yale so far, and I really feel that I gained a lot from this class. Professor Lafargue did an excellent job with choosing the materials for the class and conducting each class to allow us to have thoughtful discussions about the readings and issues discussed within the books.
Yes, I LOVED the readings we did, but it is a lot of reading!

I would definitely recommend this course because the information you learn is unmatched! Learning new ways to analyze historical trends and apply them to our present day BLM movement help us to be engaged global citizens in our everyday lives. It's not too often that we can explore these sort of conversations in an academic setting.

I would recommend this course to most students. If you're already very familiar with the content the course covers, don't expect groundbreaking new information, but Prof. Lafargue does a good job of framing the class through compelling paradigms and chooses some interesting, non-obvious readings.
Yes, class discussions are enjoyable and readings are enlightening.
